text:
ECOLOGY

Ecosystem is a stable environment regardless of size. in which living and non-living organisms interact and in which materials and energy are used and recirculated e.g. pond, lake, and forest are large ecosystems. 

An ecosystem includes the living (biotic) organisms (all the populations) in an area and the non-living (abiotic) aspects of the environment and their interactions.

Biosphere is the part of the earth which life exists.

A population is a group of organisms belonging to the same species that live in the same area and interact with one another.

A community is all of the populations of different species that live in the same area and interact with one another.

A niche is the role an organism plays in its ecosystem. Essentially, what services it provides and does in an ecosystem. For example, a sardines’ niche would be to eat algae and phytoplankton and serve as a food source for many different fish species.

Levels of organization in ecology include the population, community, ecosystem, and biosphere.

UNN PUTME Example

The study the organism and the environment of an abandoned farmland is the ecology of

A. a community B. a population C. a population D. an ecosystem

(D. The study the organism and the environment of an abandoned farmland is the ecology of ecosystem, 2017/2018 II, no 1)

 

Food chain and Food Web

A food chain is a linear sequence, linear feeding relationship of organisms through which nutrients and energy pass as one organism eats another. It also means the linear transfer of the sunlight energy from producers (green plants) to consumers (animals) as organisms feed on one another In a food chain, each organism occupies a different trophic level, defined by how many energy transfers separate it from the basic input of the chain. A food chain represents a single pathway by which energy and matter flow through an ecosystem.

Food webs consist of many interconnected food chains and are more realistic representation of consumption relationships in ecosystems. In a food web a particular organism has the probability of being eaten by various other organism in other food chains, e.g a lion can feed on a crocodile although lion is not in aquatic ecosystem. Food web is a complex feeding relationship and its composed of many food chains.

 

Types of Pyramids

A pyramid of numbers 

A pyramid of numbers is a graphical representation that shows the number of organisms at each trophic level. It is an upright pyramid because in an ecosystem, the producers are always more in number than other trophic levels.

Primary producers (e.g. grasses and Peyton) are the highest in number and occupies the base of the prism, while tertiary consumers (Lions, bears etc.) are the smallest in number and are at the apex of the pyramid. 

Primary consumers are animal which feed directly on plants (producers) e.g. goat feeding on grass, the secondary consumers feed on the primary consumers (lion feeding on goat). Tertiary consumers feed on the secondary consumers e.g. lion feeding on crocodile).

Pyramid of Energy

This indicates the amount of energy flow at each level and the role which the organisms play in the transfer of energy. There is decrease in energy from one trophic level to another along the food chain. Producers have the highest energy.

Each step of the food chain in the energy pyramid is called a trophic level. Plants or other photosynthetic organisms (autotrophs) are found on the first trophic level, at the bottom of the pyramid. The next level will be the herbivores, and then the carnivores that eat the herbivores.

Factors that affect the Ecosystem

Biotic factor is any living component that affects the population of another organism, or the environment (ecosystem). This includes producers (plants and some microbes) and consumers, animals that consume the organism, and the living food that the organism consumes. Biotic factors also include human influence, pathogens, and disease outbreaks. 

An abiotic factor is a non-Iiving component in the environment. This can be either a chemical or physical presence. Abiotic factors fall into three basic categories: climatic, edaphic and social. Climatic factors include humidity, sunlight and factors involving the climate. Edaphic refers to soil conditions, so edaphic abiotic factors include soil and geography of the land. Social factors include how the land is being used and water resources in the area.

Temperature and rainfall are the most important abiotic factors.

Soil is the outer layer of the earth's crust capable of supporting vegetation. The soil's ability to retain water is strongly related to particle size; water molecules hold more tightly to the fine particles of a clay soil than to coarser particles of a sandy soil, so clays generally retain more water. Loamy soil is the best for agriculture and it has a moderate water holding capacity

Transpiration is a biological process that involves the movement of water through a plant to the atmosphere, from the aerial parts of the plants. It is an important part of water cycle.

Humidity is expressed as the percentage of water vapour present in the atmosphere. The higher the relative humidity of the outside atmosphere, the lower the rate of transpiration and vice versa. Environmental factors can affect the rate of transpiration include light, temperature, wind, humidity. When humidity is low like during hot weather or sunshine, it increases transpiration.

Holozoic (Heterotrophic) nutrition a type of nutrition in animals and few plants which are not capable of making their own food but depend upon already made food which must be digested, absorbed, assimilated and ejected. This is typical of animal nutrition which is characterized by ingestion, digestion, absorption, assimilation and egestion.

A decomposer is an organism that decomposes, or breaks down, organic material such as the remains of dead organisms. Decomposers include bacteria and fungi. These organisms carry out the process of decomposition, which all living organisms undergo after death.

Saprophytic fungi like mushrooms feed on dead plant and animal remains. Many are extremely beneficial, breaking down this organic material into humus, minerals and nutrients that can be utilised by plants. Without these fungi we would also disappear under a mountain of undecayed dead leaves and logs.

Denitrifying bacteria, microorganisms whose action results in the conversion of nitrates in soil to free atmospheric nitrogen, thus depleting soil fertility and reducing agricultural productivity.

Examples; Thiobacillus denitrificans, Micrococcus denitrificans, and some species of Serratia, Pseudomonas, and Achromobacter are implicated as denitrifiers.

Estuarine habitat occurs where salty water from the ocean mixes with freshwater from the land. River mouths, lagoons, and bays often constitute estuarine habitat. Within any estuary, salinity fluctuates with the seasons and tides and organisms living in such habitats must be adapted to withstand such fluctuations.

Ecological succession is the process of change in the species structure of an ecological community over time. It is a phenomenon or process by which an ecological community undergoes more or less orderly and predictable changes following a disturbance or the initial colonization of a new habitat.

Primary succession begins in barren areas, such as on bare rock exposed by a retreating glacier. The first inhabitants are lichens or plants—those that can survive in such an environment. Over hundreds of years these “pioneer species” convert the rock into soil that can support simple plants such as grasses. These grasses further modify the soil, which is then colonized by other types of plants. Each successive stage modifies the habitat by altering the amount of shade and the composition of the soil. The final stage of succession is a climax community, which is a very stable stage that can endure for hundreds of years.

An anemometer is an instrument used to measure the speed or velocity of air (gases) either in a contained flow, such as airflow in a duct, or in unconfined flows, such as atmospheric wind.

Ridging across slope will prevent erosion by forming a wall against the flow of water into the land. Contour plowing (or contour farming) is the farming practice of plowing and/or planting across a slope following its elevation contour lines. These contour lines create a water break which reduces the formation of rills and gullies during times of heavy water run-off; which is a major cause of soil erosion.

Biodegradable substances are substances that are capable of being broken down (decomposed) rapidly by the action of microorganisms e.g. decomposers like termite, earthworm. They include stems, leaves, food scraps, cotton, wool, wood, human and animal waste, miniatured products based on natural materials (such as paper, and vegetable-oil based soaps). Synthetic products like metals, crude oil are not biodegradable.

 

UNN PUTME Example

1. Which of the following ecological factors are common to both terrestrial and aquatic habitats?

A. Rainfall, temperature, light and wind B. Salinity, rainfall, temperature and light C. Tides, wind, rainfall and altitude D. pH, salinity, rainfall and humidity

(A. Rainfall, temperature, light and wind, 2017/2018 II, no 13)

 

2. The most important factor that determines the different types of vegetation is 

A. light B. wind C. temperature D. rainfall

(D. rainfall)

 

3. The following are some examples of food chain in the savanna terrestrial ecosystem except

A. grass → zebra → lion B. diatoms → crayfish → bony fish C. seeds → weaverbird → civets D. leaves → elephant → vulture

(B. diatoms → crayfish → bony fish are all found in aquatic ecosystem, 2005/2006, no 10)

 

4. One adaptation shown by hydrophyte in freshwater habitats 

A. leaves reduced to spine B. poor development of roots and xylem tissues C. waxy cuticle on shoot surface D. weII-developed roots and supporting system 

(B. Hydrophytes are group of plants that have adapted to life in wet places or aquatic habitat. They have little to no root system because it is easier for them to obtain nutrients from water surfaces, 2018/2019, no 1)

 

5. The speed of the wind can be measured with an instrument called 

A. hydrometer  B. secchi disc C. anemometer  D. wind vane 

(C. An anemometer is an instrument used to measure the speed or velocity of air (gases) either in a contained flow, such as airflow in a duct, or in unconfined flows, such as atmospheric wind, 2017/2018, no 3)

 

6. The soil with the highest water-retaining capacity is 

A. clayey soil B. stoney soil C. sandy soil D. loamy soil 

(A. The soil's ability to retain water is strongly related to particle size; water molecules hold more tightly to the fine particles of a clay soil than to coarser particles of a sandy soil, so clays generally retain more water. Loamy soil is the best for agriculture and it has a moderate water holding capacity, 2017/2018, no 5)

 

7. Water retention in soils which are rich in

A. sand, poor in humus, and devoi of clay B. clay, and sand, but poor in sand C. clay and humus, but poor in sand D. clay, poor in humus and devoid of sand

(D. clay, poor in humus and devoid of sand, 2017/2018 II, no 11)

 

8. In a pyramid of numbers, it is common to have_____ with the smallest of individuals

A. secondary consumers B. tertiary consumers C. primary consumers D. primary producers

(B. A pyramid of numbers is a graphical representation that shows the number of organisms at each trophic level. It is an upright pyramid in light of the fact that in an ecosystem, the producers are always more in number than other trophic levels, 2007/2008, no 10)

 

9. which of the following group of factors is completely abiotic 

A. salinity, tide, plankton, turbidity. B. Temperature, pH, soil, insect. C. wind, altitude, humidity, light. D. conifers, wind, pH, rainfall.

(C. An abiotic factor is a non-Iiving component in the environment like wind, altitude, humidity, 2017/2018 II, no 9)

 

10. erosion can be reduced along a slope by 

A. ridging across slope B. ridging up slope C. ridging down the slope D. crop rotation

(A. Ridging across slope will prevent erosion by forming a wall against the flow of water into the land, 2017/2018 II, no 10)

 

11. Which of the following can bring about the greatest increase in the rate of transpiration? 

A. Increased humidity B. Reduced temperature C. Reduced wind speed D. Reduced humidity 

(D. Transpiration is a biological process that involves the movement of water through a plant to the atmosphere, from the aerial parts of the plants. It is part of water cycle, 2017/2018, no 7)

 

12. organisms living in an estuarine habitat are adapted to

A. withstand wide fluctuations in temperature B. survive only in water with a low salinity C. withstand wide fluctuations in salinity D. feed only on phytoplankton and dead organic matter.

(C. Estuarine habitat occurs where salty water from the ocean mixes with freshwater from the land. River mouths, lagoons, and bays often constitute estuarine habitat. Within any estuary, salinity fluctuates with the seasons and tides and organisms living in such habitats must be adapted to withstand such fluctuations, 2019/2020, no 11)

 

13. The influence of soil on organisms in a habitat is referred to as 

A. edaphic B. physiographic C. biotic D. topographic 

(A. Biotic factor is any living component that affects the population of another organism, or the environment (ecosystem). This includes producers (plants and some microbes) and consumers, animals that consume the organism, and the living food that the organism consumes, 2017/2018, no 15)

 

14. In an ecosystem animal which feed directly on plants are called 

A. secondary consumers B. Primary consumers C. Producers D. predators

(B. Primary consumers are animal which feed directly on plants (producers) e.g. goat feeding on grass, the secondary consumers feed on the primary consumers (lion feeding on goat)

 

15. The pollutant that is biodegradable is 

A. heavy metals B. cellophane C. sewage D. crude oil 

(C. All the option apart from sewage are not biodegradable, thus are soil pollutant, 2017/2018, no 12)

 

16. A food web is more stable than a food chain because 

A. it contains more organisms B. it is not easy to destroy C. it has greater energy source D. every organism has an alternative food source 

(D. Food webs consist of many interconnected food chains and are more realistic representation of consumption relationships in ecosystems, 2017/2018, no 6)

 

17. An important abiotic factor that affects plants and animals in their habitats is

A. turbidity B. rainfall C. wind direction D. temperature

(D. Temperature and rainfall are the most important abiotic factors, 2009/2010, no 7)

 

18. The organisms that help in recycling the material in the ecosystem are known as

A. herbivores B. carnivores C. omnivores D. decomposers

(D. A decomposer is an organism that decomposes, or breaks down, organic material such as the remains of dead organisms, 2012/2013 II, no 3)

 

19. The mushroom is an organism that feeds

A. parasitically B. holozoically C. symbiotically D. saprophytically

(D. Saprophytic fungi like mushrooms feed on dead plant and animal remains, 2012/2013 II, no 8)

 

20. In trying to find out the order in which organisms appear on a cleared plot, you are studying

A. ecosystem B. food chain C. succession D. food web

(C. Ecological succession is the process of change in the species structure of an ecological community over time, 2012/2013 II, no 15)

 

21. Nitrogen is released to the atmosphere by_____

A. nitrogen-fixing bacteria B. nitrifying bacteria C. denitrifying bacteria D. saprophytic bacteria

(C. Denitrifying bacteria, microorganisms whose action results in the conversion of nitrates in soil to free atmospheric nitrogen, thus depleting soil fertility and reducing agricultural productivity, 2015/2016, no 9)

 

22. Which is the correct order in an evolutionary sequence for the following plant groups?

A. bacteria ⟶ ferns ⟶ algae ⟶ mosses ⟶seed plants.

B. bacteria ⟶ ferns ⟶ mosses ⟶ algae ⟶ seed plants.

C. bacteria ⟶ algae ⟶ mosses ⟶ ferns ⟶seed plants.

D. bacteria ⟶ mosses ⟶ algae ⟶ ferns ⟶ seed plants.

(C. bacteria ⟶ algae ⟶ mosses ⟶ ferns ⟶seed plants, 2015/2016, no 12)

 

23. Which of the following is a feature of the population pyramid of a developing country?

A. Low death rate B. Short lifespan C. Long lifespan D. Low birth rate

(B. Developing countries are, in general, countries that have not achieved a significant degree of industrialization relative to their populations, and have, in most cases, a medium to low standard of living. There is an association between low income and high population growth, 2015/2016, no 9)

 

24. What do bacteria in root nodules derive from host plant?

A. Protection and minerals B. Water and minerals C. Carbohydrates and water D. protection and carbohydrates

(D. Symbiotic bacteria called rhizobia within the nodules, producing nitrogen compounds that help the plant to grow and compete with other plants. When the plant dies, the fixed nitrogen is released, making it available to other plants and this helps to fertilize the soil, 2015/2016 II, no 12) 

 

25. The thallus of lichen consists of

A. a virus and a fungus B. algae cells and fungal hyphae C. bacterial and fungal cells D. soredium and basisiopot

(B. The lichen is a symbiotic association composed of both fungal hyphae (which is a thread-like fungal cells) providing protection and structure and algal cells (photosynthetic). The fungal partner is usually an ascomycete and is dominant to the alga which is a green or blue-green alga, 2006/2007, no 9)

 

26. A characteristic feature of tropical rainforest is that it 

A. contains trees with narrow leaves.  B. contains large number of plant species. C. contains fewer number of plant species. D. has total annual rainfall of less than 50cm. 

(B. A tropical rainforest can have more than 480 tree species per hectare. insect’s species are the most abundant in the rainforests, 2017/2018, no 9)

 

27. the mode of nutrition of sundew and bladderwort can be described as

A. saprophytic B. holozoic C. chemosynthesis D. autotrophic

(B. Holozoic (Heterortrophic) nutrition a type of nutrition in animals which are not capable of making their own food but depend upon already made food which must be digested, absorbed, assimilated and ejected, 2019/2020, no 1)

 

JAMB Examples

1. The mode of nutrition of sun dew and bladder wort can be described as

A. autotrophic B. saprophytic C. holozoic D. chemosynthetic

(C. holozoic)

 

2. Which of the following organisms is mainly found in the marine habitat?

A. Achatina B. Tilapia C. Dog fish D. Tortoise

(C. Dog fish)

 

3. Which of the following instruments is used to measure relative humidity?

A. Hydrometer B. Thermometer C. Hygrometer D. Anemometer

(C. Hygrometer)

 

4. Which of the following groups of environmental factors are density-dependent?

A. Food, salinity, accumulation of metabolites and light B. Temperature, salinity predation and disease C. Food predation, disease and accumulation of metabolites D. Temperature food disease and light

(C. Food predation, disease and accumulation of metabolites)

 

5. In which of the following biomes is the south western part of Nigeria located?

A. Temperate forest B. Tropical rainforest C. Tropical woodland D. Desert

(B. Tropical rainforest)

 

6. The significance of a very large number of termites involved in nuptial swarming is to

A. provide birds with plenty of food B. ensure their perpetuation despite predatory pressure

C. search for a favourable place to breed D. ensure that every individual gets a mate

(B. ensure their perpetuation despite predatory pressure)

 

7. The study of how and why population size change over time is

A. Population estimation B. Population dynamics C. Population ecology D. Population Cycle

(B. Population dynamics)

 

8. The increasing order of the particle size in the following soil types is 

A. cattle sand – clay-gravel B. clay – silt – sand – gravel C. silt - clay - sand - gravel D. clay - sand - silt – gravel

(B. clay – silt – sand – gravel)

 

9. The rise and fall of ocean water during the day is referred to as 

A. gravity B. a pull C. tide D. zone

(C. tide)
